key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning method learns rich representations of neuronal activity that enable high-content, label-free screening to identify genetic modifiers of activity dynamics across diverse neural interventions.
problem_solved: Scales phenotypic screening of neuronal activity without relying on manual labels or task-specific supervision, while capturing both temporal dynamics and network connectivity that determine functional phenotypes.
method: Incorporate network topology into a self-supervised representation-learning objective to encode spatiotemporal activity patterns.
Train on unlabeled neuronal activity recordings to produce compact phenotype embeddings that generalize across interventions.
Use those embeddings in a high-content screening pipeline to detect and rank genetic perturbations that modify activity dynamics.
impact: Demonstrates how combining graph-aware priors with self-supervised learning yields transferable, biologically meaningful embeddings for time-series data â€” enabling scalable, label-free discovery workflows useful to ML practitioners working on representation learning, computational neurobiology, and high-throughput screening.

paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
